text:
Hi!

Together with Damien Seguin and <@UEG9ECNSU> we have been building a node-based creative-coding tool at <http://variable.io> that is JavaScript based and npm friendly: Nodes.

We have used it for all our creative coding, generative art and datavis projects for the last 3 years and it’s really changed how we think with code. If you are interested in knowing more and trying it out, we just shared an open beta today for everyone: <https://twitter.com/nodes_io/status/1328666419890954241>

You can download it on our website: <https://nodes.io/>

--- end of announcement :slightly_smiling_face:

Happy to engage in any kind of discussion from “Why on earth JS?” to “Did you find unidirectional data flow useful or troublesome?” or even help getting started.

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/nodes_io|@nodes_io>: :sparkles:The open beta is here!:sparkles:

We are so proud to present the open beta of Nodes for you all to experiment and explore with. We hope you'll love this new way of creating with code.

Download here: <https://nodes.io> <https://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1328666190659678209/pu/img/cPZD5vPT53_sczzR.jpg>

text:
Hi all,
for those who don't yet know, brother and I are working on <https://wasp-lang.dev|Wasp> - a DSL (domain specific language) for building web apps with as little boilerplate as possible. It is open-source and integrates with React/Node.js/Prisma.
Main hypothesis of the experiment: What if web framework was a DSL (we are not the first ones to try this!)?

About half a year ago I posted a prototype here, and now we have released an Alpha! It is still very early, but we have docs, it can be properly installed, and you can build an app (though it still misses many important features).

Goal of the project and our focus is to make developing web apps as easy as possible, while still being flexible enough to be used for real projects in production. In that sense, I think it should be an ok fit for FoC, since it should allow developers who are not very experienced in web development to build a full-stack production-ready web app by themselves. It does add one more layer of abstraction, but the goal is to reduce knowledge barrier.
Bigger, crazier vision is to one day also build a no-code visual editor on top of Wasp, which would allow non-developers to participate alongside developers. We are thinking this could work very good with Wasp since it is declarative, and if we manage to capture big portion of web app functionality in this declarative code, it could be easier to build such editor on top.

When using Wasp, you write code in Wasp (declarative) and Javascript together.
Compiler implemented in Haskell compiles/transpiles the source code of Wasp project into a human-readable JS based web app (which you don't care about unless you decide to eject -> take the code and leave Wasp).

We started working on Wasp about a year ago, first as a side project and then full time (we are bootstraping), and we are excited to see how far we can get with the whole concept! Right now we are trying to get first testers and contributors (actually got our first contributor couple of days ago wohooo!), while we also keep developing Wasp.

Webpage: <https://wasp-lang.dev>
Docs: <https://wasp-lang.dev/docs/>
Todo App tutorial: <https://wasp-lang.dev/docs/tutorials/todo-app> <- probably best place to get started and try it out
Github repo: <https://github.com/wasp-lang/wasp>

Thanks for any feedback!

Hi all,
for those who don't yet know, brother and I are working on
Wasp

- a DSL (domain specific language) for building web apps with as little boilerplate as possible. It is open-source and integrates with React/Node.js/Prisma.
Main hypothesis of the experiment: What if web framework was a DSL (we are not the first ones to try this!)?

About half a year ago I posted a prototype here, and now we have released an Alpha! It is still very early, but we have docs, it can be properly installed, and you can build an app (though it still misses many important features).

Goal of the project and our focus is to make developing web apps as easy as possible, while still being flexible enough to be used for real projects in production. In that sense, I think it should be an ok fit for FoC, since it should allow developers who are not very experienced in web development to build a full-stack production-ready web app by themselves. It does add one more layer of abstraction, but the goal is to reduce knowledge barrier.
Bigger, crazier vision is to one day also build a no-code visual editor on top of Wasp, which would allow non-developers to participate alongside developers. We are thinking this could work very good with Wasp since it is declarative, and if we manage to capture big portion of web app functionality in this declarative code, it could be easier to build such editor on top.

When using Wasp, you write code in Wasp (declarative) and Javascript together.
Compiler implemented in Haskell compiles/transpiles the source code of Wasp project into a human-readable JS based web app (which you don't care about unless you decide to eject -> take the code and leave Wasp).

We started working on Wasp about a year ago, first as a side project and then full time (we are bootstraping), and we are excited to see how far we can get with the whole concept! Right now we are trying to get first testers and contributors (actually got our first contributor couple of days ago wohooo!), while we also keep developing Wasp.

text: I decided to add a second summary graph to the profiler; this one (shown at the top, in purple) gives a view into the time taken on the audio thread - the critical one for good sound processing.  It is shown as continuous here, but really it is discrete; it is somewhat easier to visualise like this I think.  The graph goes more red the closer the audio thread comes to the max time slice it is given to generate audio.  The image here shows a brief bottleneck which I've zoomed into in the bottom of the profiler.  You can see that the yellow 'Audio' region is much bigger for this particular frame, compared to the next ones.  Although I don't have instrumentation for it yet, I believe this is coinciding with the arrival of the first notes into the graph - since a known problem is that some memory allocation is done at this point on the first run (and this particular stress test is playing many notes all at once).  Just something I know I need to get around to fixing. I'm satisfied the profiler is useful enough to leave alone for now, and move onto other things.

elements.text: I decided to add a second summary graph to the profiler; this one (shown at the top, in purple) gives a view into the time taken on the audio thread - the critical one for good sound processing. The graph goes more red the closer the audio thread comes to the max time slice it is given to generate audio.  The image here shows a brief bottleneck which I've zoomed into in the bottom of the profiler.  You can see that the yellow 'Audio' region is much bigger for this particular frame, compared to the next ones.  Although I don't have instrumentation for it yet, I believe this is coinciding with the arrival of the first notes into the graph - since a known problem is that some memory allocation is done at this point on the first run (and this particular stress test is playing many notes all at once).  Just something I know I need to get around to fixing. I'm satisfied the profiler is useful enough to leave alone for now, and move onto other things.

text:
Funny coincidence to see this today! I’ve been thinking a lot lately about how task specifications decompose into pieces, and how each piece is implemented in a plan. <https://willcrichton.net/expressiveness-benchmark/>

Would be interested to understand more about your plan IR, both the text -> plan and plan -> code translations.

elements.text: Funny coincidence to see this today! I’ve been thinking a lot lately about how task specifications decompose into pieces, and how each piece is implemented in a plan.
Would be interested to understand more about your plan IR, both the text -> plan and plan -> code translations.

text: We didn’t end up with an intermediate plan concept. The system is built around objects (we’re calling them gadgets) that have “parts” (composable bits of state, think components in an ECS) and “processes”

elements.text: We didn’t end up with an intermediate plan concept. The system is built around objects (we’re calling them gadgets) that have “parts” (composable bits of state, think components in an ECS) and “processes”

text: The text in the input is going directly to a process, which has a series of ordered steps like a normal imperative procedure

elements.text: The text in the input is going directly to a process, which has a series of ordered steps like a normal imperative procedure

text: What a teaser!  So what do the edges in the diagram at the end mean?  The "click" edge seems to show signals.  It appears that "add 1 to the count" is a label for the node.  The orange numbers seem to show the value of "the count."  But why the hell isn't "the count" reified as a visual object?

text: My quest to build a truly personal computer has hit a major milestone. I finally have a working reference hardware implementation for my uCISC processor at the TinyFPGA Bx board. It runs a battery of instruction tests and computes fib(24) successfully at 16MHz (4 clocks per instruction). See the readme and reference folder here: <https://github.com/grokthis/ucisc/tree/master/hardware>

attachments.title: grokthis/ucisc
attachments.text: Contribute to grokthis/ucisc development by creating an account on GitHub.

elements.text: My quest to build a truly personal computer has hit a major milestone. I finally have a working reference hardware implementation for my uCISC processor at the TinyFPGA Bx board. It runs a battery of instruction tests and computes fib(24) successfully at 16MHz (4 clocks per instruction). See the readme and reference folder here:

text:
4 clocks per instruction = 4 million instructions per second (for common instructions, excluding multiplies, memory, etc.)?

This is amazing news.

elements.text:
4 clocks per instruction = 4 million instructions per second (for common instructions, excluding multiplies, memory, etc.)?

This is amazing news.

text: It is _eye-opening_ how short all the files in <https://github.com/grokthis/ucisc/tree/master/hardware/ecp5_single_IPC> are.

elements.text: It is
eye-opening
how short all the files in
are.

text: The ecp5 version is an old implementation that never worked on hardware. The reference folder is the one to look at. In the end, the bulk of it is just one file cpu.v which is much smaller than I would have thought given what it does.

elements.text: The ecp5 version is an old implementation that never worked on hardware. The reference folder is the one to look at. In the end, the bulk of it is just one file cpu.v which is much smaller than I would have thought given what it does.

text: Yes, 4 million instructions per second for all instructions except division and TBD on multiplication. That's any combination of to/from memory including memory to memory with the other ALU operations in between.

elements.text: Yes, 4 million instructions per second for all instructions except division and TBD on multiplication. That's any combination of to/from memory including memory to memory with the other ALU operations in between.

text:
This teaser has a pretty narrow viewport -- so there are some other components you're not seeing here. We think it'll be better (both for comprehension and productivity) to rely on multiple synced representations instead of trying to present everything at once through the schematic.

The count (and everything else that isn't featured in the schematic) lands in the data sheet, which brings together _everything_ about the thing you're working on into a single editable document (structure and live values included).

By being a bit more selective about what we put into the schematic view, we can ensure that it never ends up too crowded to be useful. It provides an intuitive understanding of the flows and relationships you're looking at in the data sheet -- and by interacting in the data sheet, you can tell us where the schematic's attention should be focused.

It provides an intuitive understanding of the flows and relationships you're looking at in the data sheet -- and by interacting in the data sheet, you can tell us where the schematic's attention should be focused.

text:
> It appears that "add 1 to the count" is a label for the node.
Yep! The schematic system can provide arbitrary annotations for the nodes and wires. In this case it's showing the code of the process that runs on click. We're still experimenting with the visuals here, so that should be more clear in time.

text: This is amazing man. Gonna dig in soon.
What sort of device wishlist do you have? I know you've talked about wanting to get a computer that can drive a large monitor. Have you thought about input modalities or networking at all?

elements.text: What sort of device wishlist do you have? I know you've talked about wanting to get a computer that can drive a large monitor. Have you thought about input modalities or networking at all?

text: My early goals, at least currently, are 1) VGA 640x480 screen, 2) UART for text input, 3) nintendo era game controllers - with that I can load code over UART, send text and "type" over UART, and program some simple "games". It's a really good POC that roughly equates to the capabilities of a C64 at that point and I can switch focus to better uCISC and higher level languages and see where I can take it.
